About this Documentation
 
 

Welcome

 
 
 

Welcome to the documentation for the Autodesk® Beast™ 2015 lighting and global illumination software. This page is intended to direct you to the resources you need to get up and running with this software as quickly as possible.

For new users

Step 1: Get your license

In order to use the Beast API and tools, you need a valid license file provided by Autodesk.

If you have not already received your license, request it right away from Autodesk Support at gameware@autodesk.com. You need to set up your license immediately in order to begin working with the examples and API supplied in this package.

For details on setting up your license, see Licensing.

Step 2: Read the Getting Started section

The Getting Started with Beast chapter of this documentation contains some general information about what Beast is, how it works, and how you can put it to work for you. It is highly recommended that you read at least this section closely before beginning to work with the API or to study the examples supplied in this package. Investing a small amount of time now in acquiring a basic understanding of the terminology, main objects and basic principles of Beast will pay dividends later as you try to understand the examples and to integrate Beast into your own project.

Step 3: Look at the sample code

The example projects included in this package show Beast at work in a variety of contexts. They provide working illustrations of how to use the Beast API to achieve different lighting effects. Full source code is included for these examples. You can use this code as a reference and a model when writing your own Beast integration.

For details about compiling and running the examples, see Getting Started with the Beast Examples.

Step 4: Familiarize yourself with Beast

Use the new Maya plug-in to familiarize yourself with Beast. The Maya plug-in contains full source code to help you understand how it works and extend it as required.

Step 5: Integrate Beast into your own project

When you are ready to integrate Beast into your own game, you should follow along with the Integrating the Beast API chapter of this documentation. Although the exact procedures that must be followed in order to integrate Beast successfully are necessarily dependent on the specific nature of your game engine, scene construction and lighting system, this section outlines the main tasks involved. Once you have completed the tasks in this section, and seen from the examples how to achieve different effects, you should be able to get your own scenes lit using Beast.

For returning users

For a description of the new features in this release, and instructions on the changes you must make in your code or production pipeline in order to upgrade to the current version of Beast, see the Migration Guide, or jump directly to:

  • What's New in This Release
  • Upgrade Requirements for This Release
